title: Makar Sankranti (Kite Festival)
hero_image_alt: Colorul kites in the sky during Uttarayan
short_description: A pan-Indian solar festival famous for the International Kite Festival in Gujarat.
long_description:
Makar Sankranti marks the transition of the Sun into the zodiac sign of Capricorn (Makara), signaling the end of winter and the start of longer days. Unlike most Hindu festivals which follow the lunar cycle, this follows the solar cycle and usually falls on January 14th.

While celebrated differently across India (Pongal in Tamil Nadu, Magh Bihu in Assam), the most visually spectacular celebration is 'Uttarayan' in Gujarat. The sky becomes a battlefield of kites. Millions of colorful paper kites fill the horizon, and the air resonates with shouts of 'Kai Po Che!' (I have cut the kite!). It is a day of rooftop parties, music, sunglasses, and eating 'undhiyu' (a mixed vegetable delicacy) and jaggery-sesame sweets.
significance: Celebrates the sun's journey northwards and the harvest.
key_rituals: Kite Flying: The main attraction in Western India.
Holy Dip: Bathing in sacred rivers (Ganga Sagar Mela).
Sesame Sweets: Exchanging 'Til-Gud' to sweeten relationships.
Donation: Giving charity to the needy.

top_places.title: Jaipur
top_places.best_to_experience: Kite flying from the rooftops of the old city with the forts in the background.

top_places.title: Ganga Sagar (West Bengal)
top_places.best_to_experience: Taking a holy dip where the Ganges meets the Bay of Bengal.

practical_info.dress_tips: Sunglasses and hats are mandatory for looking up at kites all day. Sunscreen too.
practical_info.safety_tips: Kite strings (manjha) can be sharp and dangerous for birds and bikers. Be careful on rooftops.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Rooftops are not accessible, but the Riverfront event is.

faqs.a: Yes! Buy one from a street stall for ₹10 and ask a local to help you launch it. It's harder than it looks.
